Introduction

Commercial aviation has a severe impact on the climate due to the emission of harmful particulates and gases such as carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, and lead. In 2017, aviation resulted in 859 million tonnes of CO2, which is roughly 2% of man-made carbon emissions [10]. According to estimates, one round-trip trans-Atlantic flight emits enough carbon dioxide to melt 30 square feet of Arctic sea ice. It is essential to consider efforts that promise to limit the adverse effects of aviation. While there are joint efforts in the industry, such as the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) [1], they are mostly voluntary, market-based, and have modest targets. We explore and propose machine learning methods to optimize flight time given a source and a destination. The key insight is that an aircraft can significantly reduce flight time by choosing a routing that has favorable winds. Our proposal is two-fold: use machine learning to (1) improve winds aloft forecasts and (2) derive flight policies that are optimal for time to reach the destination. We propose using the network of aircraft already in the air as surrogate sensors that continually update and inform about the winds. We also explore the idea of sequential decision making via contextual bandits to derive optimal flight policies. Shaving an hour of flight time on average can reduce carbon dioxide emissions by over 2500 kg, making the methods described in this paper fairly useful.

1.1 Improving Wind Forecasts

The core idea is to use publicly available information from the large number of aircraft aloft to improve wind forecasts. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) publishes Winds Aloft reports for static wind station sites at a discrete set of altitudes. We refine these forecasts by considering how fast an aircraft is traveling over the ground (ground speed), which is highly informative about the latent winds that an aircraft is experiencing at that location. Formally, we use Gaussian Processes (GPs) [6] as they provide an efficient updating procedure for conditioning phenomena at one location based on observations at other locations. 

We use publicly available data from aircraft in flight to improve wind forecasts. The data includes the ground velocities of the aircraft, which we use to estimate the winds encountered by the aircraft. We use a potential function to relate the ground velocity of the aircraft to the encountered winds via the wind triangle.
